awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: IA: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Financial Market Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an interdisciplinary project involving computer science and economics. The big data problem to be addressed concerns how to analyze and understand financial trading, and its effects on the stock market. The project introduces new behavioral models of financial trading and applies big data techniques to implement them.  The project will foster research on the financial ecosystem of machine-machine and machine-human interactions by bringing financial economists and data scientists together in a series of workshops.

The PIs will work with the National Center for Supercomputing and develop a new and more accurate taxonomy of trading frequencies by categorizing high frequency traders (HFT), buy-side algorithmic traders (BAT) and human traders using two proprietary high frequency datasets. The workshops will foster research on the implications of the new financial ecosystem for the overall financial system and the economy in general, as well as creating new metrics and data for the discipline of finance in economics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project successfully transformed big data in finance into a recognized and thriving field through interdisciplinary collaboration between the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) and the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA). The grant had two key components: one supporting the PI’s research on machine-machine and machine-human interactions in trading, and the other funding more than ten NBER conferences to foster collaboration between financial economists and experts in high-performance computing (HPC) and big data.

Research

On September 18, 2024, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) unanimously adopted a rule to reduce transaction costs for ordinary U.S. investors significantly. This rule change extensively cites research supported by this grant, reduce tick size, lot size, and the maximum fees charged by stock exchanges. Research supported by this grant provides the economic foundation for these reductions. 

  1. Reducing Tick Size: The smallest price change (tick size) for stocks above $1 is currently 1 cent. Therefore, tick size sets a lower bound of 1 cent for the bid-ask spread. Research by Li, Wang, and Ye (2021) and Li and Ye (2024) demonstrate that the one-cent tick size inflates transaction costs for investors and creates rents for market makers, incentivizing high-frequency trading (HFT). The new rule reduces the tick size to 0.5 cents for stocks priced at or greater than $1 per share if the time-weighted average spread of the stock during a specified three-month evaluation period is lower than 1.5 cents. This new rule can potentially reduce transaction costs by up to 50% for investors.
  2. Reducing Lot Size: The minimum lot size for most U.S. stocks is 100 shares. For example, if a stock’s best ask price is $2000 and the best bid price is $1998, these quotes apply to a minimum of 100 shares. Research by Li and Ye (2024) shows that market makers face lower adverse selection risks for smaller lot sizes (e.g., 10 shares), leading to better prices. The new rule accelerates the reduction of lot sizes for stocks priced above $250, significantly lowering transaction costs for high-priced stocks.
  3. Reducing Exchange Fees: Under Reg NMS, the National Best Bid and Offer (NBBO) determines stock routing based on gross price, overlooking exchange fees. Research by Li, Ye, and Zheng (2023) found that Reg NMS routes 62% of orders to worse net prices when adjusted for fees. The new rule reduces exchange fee caps from 0.3 cents to 0.1 cents per share, which would reduce the fee distortions.

In addition to aiding regulators and ordinary investors, the research supported by the grant provides formulas to help U.S. firms enhance their value. Li and Ye (2024) derive a simple formula for determining the optimal price per share for U.S.-listed firms. While economists often assume that price and quantity are continuous variables, in reality, both are discrete. U.S. regulations enforce a minimum tick size of one cent and a minimum lot size of 100 shares. The PI’s research demonstrates that less volatile stocks should choose higher prices, effectively making pricing more continuous and quantities more discrete. Despite variations in optimal prices across firms, the research finds that all companies achieve their liquidity-maximizing prices when their bid–ask spreads equal two ticks—where frictions from discrete pricing balance those from discrete lot sizes. Li and Ye (2024) show that adopting liquidity-maximizing pricing could increase the median value of U.S. stocks by 106 basis points and boost total U.S. market capitalization by $93.7 billion.

Outreach

Over the past six years, the grant supported annual NBER Summer and Winter Big Data conferences, bringing together leading finance and high-performance computing scholars. To enhance accessibility, these conferences were live-streamed on YouTube, fostering an inclusive academic and professional community. The Review of Financial Studies (RFS), a top three journal in finance, published two special issues for papers presented at these conferences, documenting six years of progress in big data in finance. The grant also supports six video-recorded public lectures exploring the connection between big data, finance, and public policy.

Defining the Field of Big Data in Finance

At the project’s inception, the concept of big data in finance was neither clearly defined nor widely recognized. The classical definition of big data—characterized by the three Vs (volume, velocity, and variety)—originates from engineering and computer science but does not fully address the opportunities and challenges in finance. Financial economists primarily focus on applying tools to answer pressing economic questions, differentiating their approach from engineers and statisticians who develop these tools.

The first and most critical step in establishing a new field is to define its scope. Through grant-supported conferences, a three-pronged framework was introduced: large size, high dimension, and complex structure (see Goldstein, Spatt, and Ye (2021 and 2024) for details). While this definition may still evolve, it provides a foundational starting point for future research and advancements for big data in finance.
